text: <@U0VPRTZC7|markusi> has joined the channel
What are people’s opinion of Android’s View system?
Could you be a bit more specific?
I guess that is a bit general

I’m wondering a couple different things, really.
1) Quality of implementation
2) Opinion of defining layouts in XML
3) Could things be simplified? Could Android benefit from adopting Web patterns like Web Components rather than reimplementing a proprietary alternative?
(Last one isn’t saying “Hey, let’s build web apps” it’s saying “let’s build native apps using what’s already there”)
I also question the need for RecyclerView
Why isn’t recycling an implementation detail?
I think anko has the right approach
Using a DSL is way better than XML
I like XML personally, after having worked on some swing based programs before :neutral_face:
(Almost) Everything else out there besides web sucks royally
right, but pretty much every platform has nice DSLs now
especially Web
I’ve wondered why CSS wasn’t improved upon for Android
instead of this weird XML system we have now
No. no css please
<@U08GFT5V5>: definitely not CSS in it’s current form
I’d like to see web assembly replace it all, really

1) Bad. 22.5k LOC `View` class is enough to justify it. Most extensions of views require inheritance, which is not good. Platform views are usually hard or impossible to modify so one has to copy-paste their code.
HTML/JS/CSS replaced by a bytecode
please no… css
/gif andre no
<@U0RGXBYUD>: platform stuff is, more often than not, made final
TextView - 10194 LoC
Often not actually. But designed really badly.
I think an inheritance-based view system was the wrong way to go
but that’s what Java gave them, I guess
How else are they supposed to do it?
It’s java
Composition
By delegation maybe
By providing extension points
game engines typically just have game entities exist as an ID, and then attach bundles of properties
which is also more or less what the DOM does
That being said, you could make your own UI toolkit that way
Basically render components in surface view
2) XML is fine, DSL could be fine too. I would say almost any format is OK :simple_smile:
<@U08GFT5V5>: I hope you mean TextureView :simple_smile:
That’s what I said :smile:
<@U0RGXBYUD>: yeah I’m less concerned about the exact format
<@U08GFT5V5> Unfortunately it’s nearly impossible to make it look like native UI on all devices.
That’s what many projects try to do and usually they fail.
<@U0RGXBYUD>: what is “native ui”, though?
just interacting with the default toolkit, no?
<@U0RGXBYUD>: might explain the 20k loc :smile:
If it doesn’t work right on all devices, increase loc
<@U053LEHJN>: I mean having the same appearance as built-in views.
ah, well I think that’d actually be easy to duplicate
Android has a well defined “box model”, so to speak

<@U08GFT5V5>: Actually no :simple_smile: 20k loc is because this class does everything and most of new view functionality is added to this class. It could have been decomposed but I assume it’s too late now.

It’s not easy because you havve to update your rendering code every time something changes in OS. Moreover the UI components look differently depending on manufacturer and API level, which system components get for free and you have to mimic.
The idea here is what if you made your own UI toolkit. That rendered components in the same way game engines do
You should be able to get a similar experience across devices
I’m saying just about this idea.

Yep, you can do that. And that’s why I wrote this comment:
> <@U08GFT5V5> Unfortunately it’s nearly impossible to make it look like native UI on all devices.
So if you do not care you UI looks differently from other applications then having your own renderer is fine.
Ah, i see. Good point
3) I think every answer will be just speculation. But I would prefer the UI system didn’t rely on web technologies.
<@U053LEHJN>: And the question about `RecyclerView` I do not get. What do you mean be making recycling an implementation detail?
well, I guess it already is, now with RecyclerView
but with ListView you had to explicitly enable recycling with the view holder pattern
No, this pattern has nothing in common with recycling.
It’s just caching.
that’s what recycling is
I mean not caching of cell views, but caching of references to views within cells.
well, the view holder is used on top of the view reuse
I said view holder since they’re used in tandem
Let’s say you have a view with a title and an icon inside. The view holder could be used to avoid calling `findViewById()` every time `getView()` is called.
<@U0RGXBYUD>: I know how the pattern works :simple_smile:
If we're talking about the XML stuff
I think the drag and drop that iOS has is far superious regarding the drag and drop
not looking at the XML
Android Studio's drag and drop sucks
The main problem with `ListView` was that you had to use `convertView`. Otherwise recycling didn’t work.
(Didn't follow the convo)
I don’t think I’ve ever seriously used the visual layout editor
<@U053LEHJN>: me neither
it’s just more of a hassle
i never trusted it by default
And me :simple_smile:
<@U053LEHJN>: see? A hassle.
It should make some stuff like alignment easier imo.
It should be better to use the design tool.
well, is a design tool really necessary?
why can’t the DSL just be better
Personally I would say yes
There's a reason something like illustrator exists
for SVG
Why don't we have such things for Android?
Good tools
It would immediately show us everything
Perhaps even decently show a recyclerview
Alignment would be a lot easier imo in the first place.
i think anko is terrible
xml is pretty good for resources on android imo
have you ever tried to use autolayout, for instance?
<@U060Q7J2Y>: what do you not like about Anko?
what does it do better than xml?
…do you want me to list all the reasons? :stuck_out_tongue:
anko solves no problems imo
The problem with XML is pretty evident by looking at the data-binding library
<@U060Q7J2Y>: I've done some simple iOS/OSX stuff and I actually really like their layout tool
they’re trying to shoehorn logic into XML
and history has shown that to be a really bad idea
not to mention you have overhead with layout inflation
i like what anko is trying to do, but in practice i've run into a lot of hiccups getting stuff working
<@U0546QERR>: I could probably help with any issues
i've worked around them and figured them out, maybe i just would like those things to be laid out up front
there really isn't too much documentation
isn't layout inflation more efficient than calling addView() 20 times hence re-measuring and re-layouting the whole thing?
<@U04TK850N>: addView is exactly what inflation does
measurement and layout isn’t done until the next time the event loop runs
all styles, style inheritance, configuration etc are based on inflation.
well I'd hope they call it more optimal than what the average dev does :smile:
you do avoid the xml parsing overhead
what overhead
which wasn't really a problem
lol
but yeah
that’s done at compile time
not runtime
<@U060Q7J2Y>: No, it compiles to a binary format, but it is not compiled to straight bytecode to be executed
there is still a parsing step
right
but it’s trivial now
and it still has to perform lookups of classes through reflection
so there is overhead
a measurable amount, as I’ve stated in the past
if you say so :simple_smile:
the whole thing is pretty unappealing to me
to each, their own
but there are pretty clear benefits to using a DSL in the same language you’re writing the app in as opposed to switching to XML
are they?
i dont feel that way
you haven’t really pointed out any benefits to staying with XML
you haven’t pointed out any tangible benefits of forgoing it
<@U060Q7J2Y>: type-safety is a big one
no inflation overhead, nor inflation-related errors
i never liked using xml in the beginning, but the fact is it's a pretty well-established framework for resources
like view attribute mishaps
if google had done anko from the start it would have been great
i mean, if that was possible in java lol
it exists for java
technically yes, it just wouldn’t be as pretty
okay well, it's not really java as I read the README: <https://github.com/tobykurien/Xtendroid>

attachments.title: tobykurien/Xtendroid
attachments.text: Xtendroid is a DSL (domain-specific language) for Android that greatly reduces boilerplate code while providing great tooling support

text: it has a sample similar to anko but adds more stuff to the mix
even json layouts would look nicer than xml for me
json lacks the attributes
and it exists too btw, even able to dynamically load JSON from the web. makes A/B testing easy
<https://github.com/Avocarrot/json2view>

attachments.title: Avocarrot/json2view
attachments.text: json2view - Update native Android UI on the fly

text: I don’t really mind the XML
it has it’s annoyances
but it isn’t really _that_ bad for this. The tools should be better
the tools would be great if the team only had to focus on one language instead of multiple :wink:
<@U053LEHJN>: are you suggesting that we code UI in java?
/gif shame shame
not necessarily, I even stated that how UIs are declared isn’t my biggest pain point
<@U0VQPS150|yeomansiii> has joined the channel
<@U0VQN2N9W|menvinay> has joined the channel

Hey guys, if you make a new app as business, what would you choose as your minSdkVer? I know it depends on how much share you want to cover, or what functionality you want to use; however I am not sure what would be the current “Best Practice” at this moment. Specifically, I am not sure whether 15 or 16 should be chosen.
erm, 21 is way too high
16 is good
Take a look here: <http://developer.android.com/intl/zh-cn/about/dashboards/index.html>

attachments.title: Dashboards | Android Developers
attachments.text: page.metaDescription=An overview of device characteristics and platform versions that are active in the Android ecosystem.

text: 16 covers most of the bases and the support libraries go back even farther.  The only reason to use 21+ is if you need something that is not available in <21, like the Camera 2 api
thanks, <@U0VQPS150> ! Is there any reason to omit 15?
I think I started with 15 but moved it up to 16 at some point because I was trying to do something that wasn't available.
You can start with 15, Android Studio will let you know if you are trying to use something that requires a higher min sdk
super! thanks for your advise!
Mhm, good luck!
<@U0LH6B4AW>: I wouldn't go out of your way to support 15 though, it's only 2.3% of devices.  If you end up having to move to 16, I would do that over trying to do some kind of workaround for 15.
thanks, that’s what I noticed as well. I will discuss with my team! :simple_smile:
<@U0VQPS150>: <@U060Q7J2Y> is a GDE, he knows what he’s talking about
I’d go further and suggest targeting android-O
the Html.fromHtml glitch in N was just killer, can’t wait for it’s market share to drop to 0
who knew they were rendering _everything_ with HTML and Trident up until now?
<@U0LH6B4AW>: in all seriousness: I can tell you that 19 is probably the best bet
apps for government contracts have begun setting that as the minimum
Why would that be necessary unless you need something from that api that isn't offered in pervious APIs?
because KitKat rules and Jelly Bean drools, obviously
There’s more to Android versions than the APIs. Lots of bugs the further back you go.
I guess it just depends on how much you want to test
just remember that the Android Dashboard graphs are an _extremely_ worst-case perspective
i’d say do 21 only because if you’re _starting_ now, by the time you ship, all your customers will likely be on 21.
ime, active users (who buy stuff, etc.) are on 21.
really depends on your market, outside the US is obviously different
<@U060Q7J2Y>: yeah, that's probably a good call
if you have an app out now - sure 15/16 is fine
but if you’re just starting, don’t waste your time supporting old versions
<@U0VR9NT8X|sd> has joined the channel
